title: 115_s2031
content: The "Kisatchie National Forest Land Conveyance Act" authorizes the conveyance of certain Federal land in Louisiana for market value consideration. The Act defines terms like "Collins Camp Properties" and "Secretary" for clarity. The Secretary is authorized to convey Federal land in Louisiana by quitclaim deed, including a 2.16-acre parcel, to Collins Camp Properties. During a 1-year period, Collins Camp Properties has the first right of purchase by providing consideration to the Secretary. The Secretary is authorized to convey Federal land in Louisiana to Collins Camp Properties by quitclaim deed, including up to 47.92 acres of land in Winn Parish. The Secretary may configure the land to maximize marketability or achieve management objectives and establish terms and conditions for the conveyance. Consideration for the conveyance must be in cash and equal to the market value of the land. The Act authorizes the conveyance of Federal land in Louisiana to Collins Camp Properties by cash payment equal to the market value determined by appraisal or competitive sale. The Secretary must disclose hazardous substances but is not required to remediate them, with no impact on the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980. The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 applies to the conveyances of Federal land. The Secretary shall deposit proceeds from the sale of Federal land into the fund established under the Sisk Act. Administration of the fund is outlined in section 6. Collins Camp Properties must cover appraisal costs and administrative/environmental analyses for Federal land conveyance. Offers for land acquisition must include approval from Forest Service special use authorization holders. Failure to provide approval requires Collins Camp Properties to manage the authorization per its terms. As a condition of conveyance, Collins Camp Properties must administer the special use authorization until it expires.
